title: What are good exercises for beginning writers? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have several go to exercises. I’ve been doing them a long time. This is a variation on one I was taught by Noreen Stone who was my first screenwriting instructor. I like to sit in a public place, a cafe, a train station, an airport, and pick people out. It might be a couple at a table, it might be two people arguing across the street - it doesn’t matter, your eye will guide you. Then, I write a story about them. I use the real details I’m seeing (he’s wearing his best suit, but it doesn’t fit as well as it used to) (She’s deliberately dressed down, trying hard not to send the wrong signals…) their shoes, how close they sit, the gestures they make, and I invent an entire story around them. Why are they there, whats the core drama? You find so much in these little details, and they, in themselves, inform the drama a little further. What does this teach us as writers in fiction? Details matter. What details you choose to give your reader change their perception, and deepen their sense of connection to the reality of your story. In training yourself to see these details in others, you learn to see them in your own fictional characters. Just don’t stare too hard, or you’ll creep them out. The moment they’re aware of the observation, you’ve altered the experiment forever.

Have a small pocket notebook with you at all times and write down your observations, listening to people speaking: copying down dialogue. And any thoughts you have that you find interesting or ideas. And questions you want answered. Larry David still has a small notebook with him, always. Journal. You must write in this everyday. The theme here is discipline…a writer writes.
